‚Äâ After seeing a whole bunch of heavy handed "dos and don'ts" floating around, I decided to do one of my own. Why not, right? Not really a bunch of advice, just a few things I do and saves me a lot of headache, time, and stress. These are habits/culture I have picked up/developed over time. I have been there 300 years ago when Muglers were considered affordable high end and clones were thought of as knock offs, and then CDNIM became this underground resistance, and now we are here. Hopefully this helps some of you **Blind buying is viable only when:** You have done a good amount of research and are *very* familiar with the scent profiles/accords from other fragrances. That is to say if you like fig on frag1, doesn't mean you will like it in frag 2. But if you have liked it in frags 1-3, you will probably like it in 4, if the reviews (a lot of them) are saying it is good. There is still a chance you might not, but after these two criteria, that gets slim. **Decants are great for elevating your fragrance game:** A lot of people think of it as waste, but if you are new and haven't sampled 100s of frags, get decants. I have used fragrancenet for a long time, and I have always filled out one or two decants to get free shipping (most decants are between 2-8 CAD, more expensive, but not when it saved me 12$ of shipping). There might be good local sellers selling decants, and there are international shippers with some good reviews as well. Once you have reached that level, your blind buying success will go up if that's your thing. Or keep getting decants. You do you. **AIs are a great tool for research:** Right now its almost exclusively Gemini. If you know how to talk to AI efficiently (like its the monkey's paw which also needs a very clear and short statements) you can save yourself hours and hours of research as it can crawl the forums, assign points, give you a summary, ranking, whatever you want. If you want, I can show you some examples **Buying off of Amazon/eBay is safe if you know where to look:** Check the sellers, check how far back the reviews go, and generally how positive they are. If you don't want to put in the work, get a browser add on like Fakespot **If you are looking for specific profiles:** You can use Parfumo/Frgrantica. Parfumo can be curated way more - [here](https://www.parfumo.com/s_perfumes_x.php?v=grid&filter=&b_id=2163%2C17122%2C13458%2C385%2C2549%2C1135%2C351%2C189%2C582%2C8997%2C1808%2C8692%2C2819%2C8430%2C7397%2C10107%2C18424%2C2019%2C14885%2C8487%2C13722%2C16792%2C18829%2C17719&m_id=&pf_id=&c_id=&n_inc_id=&n_exc_id=&nc_inc_id=&nc_exc_id=&t_id=&o=nr_desc&filter=&g_m=1&g_f=1&g_u=1&y_t=2&y_0=&y_1=0&y_2=0&y_3=&n_t=1&cl_35=0&cl_26=0&cl_13=0&cl_14=0&cl_38=0&cl_15=0&cl_16=0&cl_17=0&cl_18=0&cl_27=0&cl_31=0&cl_19=0&cl_20=0&cl_21=0&cl_22=0&cl_36=0&cl_37=0&cl_34=0&cl_33=0&cl_23=0&cl_24=0&cl_9=0&cl_10=0&cl_11=0&cl_12=0&cl_25=0&cl_6=0&cl_7=0&cl_32=0&cl_8=0&cl_5=0&cl_4=0&cl_3=0&cl_1=0&cl_2=0) is a list of filters with the clone brands I have used (there might be more but if I haven't used them, I didnt add them to the filter), just look for the note group you want and take it from there. Once you get a result, google the frag's notes to make sure the notes in parfumo weren't wrong **"Nuclear" doesn't have to be a thing:** You are not likely to wear the same clothing for 10 hours+, so anything that pushes past 8-10 hours doesn't add that much value, at least to me. But anything that lasts longer, *likely* projects more as well, if its an EDP or the old school chemical warfare grade EDTs. Extraits are by design heavier to last longer, but with less alcohol, project less. Ideally, I want a few nuclears but I don't aim for most in my collection to be. **Always check multiple shops even if they are international:** Specially if you are buying multiple frags - chances are at the other retailer across the ocean is charging you twice for the shipping but their frags being cheaper will work out cheaper total order cost (for the sites that do duty paid shipping like Joma, Fragrancenet and FragranceX) **Don't discount smaller houses:** Armaf and Lattafa were once little known in NA. CDNIM used to cost 20$. There are new houses popping up (could be an old house previously not in the spotlight), relatively unknown but doing solid work. I recently got some Azhas for 20 CAD. These easily match most of my 30$ stuff. I'll review them in a week when they have matured - they are getting better every day. Not saying blind buy, just give them a chance. **Clone Perfumeries are your friend:** I make a distinction between mass production houses like Lattafa where they have a formula and mass producing them based on it. There's always going to be quality and batch variations. Smaller entities, like a perfumery that makes approximation is using the exact formula 1:1 they set as the recipe for a clone in every bottle. The quality will be higher on average. Cost is a different thing though....

After that first hour, it begins to turn into sort of a barbershop-lite fragrance. Sage jumps out to meld with the lavender. This keeps it from feeling like a "creamy" fougere. Aromatic is definitely a good label for it. In the end, the fir and oakmoss come out as the sage fades to keep the green over top of the lavender. I enjoy this phase the most. Drakkar Bleu feels like it definitely skews older/mature. It's hard for me to immediately connect it with a good setting to wear it other than at work. Five sprays has me catching whiffs of it for about six hours. Projection is minimal after an hour, and sillage isn't great either. It's mostly a scent for the wearer to enjoy unless you go HAM on the trigger to make people recognize it's there. Bleu isn't a bottle I'm going to bin, donate or give away, but it's mostly going to be used to change up my rotation a bit from time to time. In my collection, Drakkar Bleu is behind Dylan Blue and Bvlgari Aqva Marine as a blue/aquatic, and Armaf Legesi and TF Beau de Jour easily outshine it as a fougere. I like that DB is a bit of a hybrid, but it's a jack of two trades and master of neither.
